### Fibre integration

* Generally, given a form $\omega$ of degree $d$ on some $U\times G$, and a $p$-cycle $\sigma\colon U\times\Delta^p\to G$, we define fibre integration of $\omega$ over $\sigma$ by $$\int_\sigma\omega=\int_{\Delta^p}\tilde{\sigma}^*\omega$$ where $\tilde{\sigma}\colon U\times\Delta^p\to U\times G$ is given by the projection to $U$ in the first coordinate, and $\sigma$ in the second. The resulting form is of degree $(d-p)$ on $U$, taken to be zero in the case $p>d$.

### Goals

1. Construct a map (i.e. degree-wise maps, but not necessarily giving a morphism of complexes) $\mathscr{T}_\bullet\to\mathbb{Z}(2k)[2k]$ given by integrating cycles over some _transgression_ of the $k$-th Chern class of $E$. Note that we **sheafify** $\mathscr{T}_\bullet$.
2. Everything will be in the **smooth** case first, and to consider holomorphic things we will **have to** use the Hodge filtration.
2. ~~Show that, _if_ $E$ admits a _global_ holomorphic connection, then this is indeed a morphism of complexes, and gives us a morphism $\mathscr{T}_\bullet\to\mathbb{H}^{2k}\left(X;\mathbb{Z}(2k)\right)$.~~
3. ~~Show that, _if_ $E$ does _not_ admit a global holomorphic connection, then this _fails_ to be a morphism of complexes (and that the obstruction is given exactly by the $k$-th Atiyah class?), but _does_ give us a morphism of complexes $\mathscr{T}_\bullet\to\mathbb{H}^{2k}\left(X;\mathbb{Z}(k)\right)$.~~
4. Explain why the image of $\tau$ in Deligne cohomology (in either case) under the respective morphism deserves to be called the $k$th Chern class.
